awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dinosaur Jaw Muscle Evolution and the Origins of Avian Cranial Kinesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Next to feathers and flight, movements between bones of the skull (cranial kinesis) is the most recognizable evolutionary adaptation of birds and a textbook example of musculoskeletal biomechanics used in classrooms worldwide. However, the origins of this innovation remain trapped within the dinosaur-bird fossil record. The researchers supported by this award will explore the biomechanical evolution of the avian head using 3D anatomical and computational modeling of fossil and living dinosaurs. This project will create interdisciplinary collaborations of paleontologists, comparative biomechanists and engineers. 3D models, discoveries and other data will be used to train K-12 students and teachers in mid-Missouri as well as young investigators in comparative biomechanics and avian evolution.  This project integrates anatomy, biomechanics, paleobiology, engineering, and computer science and will train a postdoctoral researcher, graduate, and undergraduate students through REU support and summer internships. Mid-Missourian and Appalachian teachers will be trained in STEM topics related to avian anatomy, biomechanics and evolution through immersive, embedded lab internships and workshops through the Inside Dinosaurs experience at University of Missouri and the Visible Interactive Dinosaur (VID) at Ohio University. Public outreach will occur through Missouri's Dinosaurs & Cavemen science exposition and VID avenues. 3D models of skulls and muscles will be made available as interactive web modules for education and research.
 
Cranial kinesis among archosaurs is a classic example of a key innovation in vertebrate evolution, resulting in enhanced cranial dexterity, extreme dietary flexibility, and the subsequent adaptive radiations of crown-clade birds. During the evolutionary transition from dinosaurs to birds, jaw muscles shifted positions, bony connections were lost, and intracranial joints became increasingly flexible. Studies supported by this award will analyze the evolution of jaw muscle forces within the cranium of non-avian and avian dinosaurs using novel 3D computational methods. These findings will allow the estimation of intracranial joint loading during feeding in extinct taxa and explore the evolution of individual jaw muscles in cranial function. The results will be integrated with neuroanatomical data to uncover the coevolutionary relationships between the brain and feeding apparatus. New 3D models of the dinosaur feeding apparatus will provide the template for numerous future studies of cranial functional morphology in other vertebrates. This work will complement and provide the necessary foundation for multi-body dynamic models of vertebrate feeding, will provide guidance for material properties testing and XROMM analysis, chondral modeling of cranial skeletal tissues, and will develop 3D datasets that can be used to test patterns of cranial modularity and skull function.  Results from the studies will be presented at scientific meetings and published in peer-reviewed journals.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
NSF Proposal Number: IOS-1456503

Title: Collaborative Research: Dinosaur Jaw Muscle Evolution and the Origins of Avian Cranial Kinesis

PI: Lawrence M. Witmer, Ohio University

Dinosaurs present unequaled potential to combine significant science with meaningful public outreach. The dinosaur and avian cranial kinesis project was a highly successful project that, over the course of 4.5 years (2015?2020) addressed both of these missions by exploring the evolution of cranial function systems?specifically the brain, skull, and feeding apparatus?in an engaging 3D virtual computer environment. This NSF-funded project has been successful in achieving its three overarching goals: (1) to document the anatomical structure of the heads of the modern-day relatives of dinosaur in unprecedented detail, (2) reconstruct the soft-tissue anatomy of the heads of a range of dinosaurs, especially on the lineage leading to bird, and (3) to use the project as a vehicle to truly have broader impacts by reaching out to a diverse public audience about science and evolution.

The grant has been extremely productive by most academic measures, yielding over three dozen peer-reviewed articles, about a dozen invited lectures (most of which were also open to the public), almost 100 conference presentations, five completed PhD dissertations (plus two more PhDs still in progress who benefitted from the grant), two undergraduate honors theses in progress, about 15 undergraduate research assistants who had some connection to the grant, over 50 outreach videos on YouTube and other social media, countless public programs and lab tours, and contributing to over 30 museum exhibits in 10 countries and 11 US states.

Intellectual Merit: A fundamental goal of the cranial kinesis project was to restore head anatomy in dinosaurs as completely as possible so as to make functional inferences. This task required not only study of dinosaur fossils, but also study of their modern relatives to better understand the soft-tissues?for example, the muscles, blood vessels, nerves, brain, eyeballs, skin?that clothe and animate the skeleton. This kind of soft-tissue reconstruction required our team to study modern-day birds, crocodilians, turtles, and lizards in minute detail, using techniques ranging from dissection, injection of blood vessels, and histological thin-slicing to microCT scanning and 3D computer visualization. We studied literally hundreds of specimens which have been accessioned into the Ohio University (OU) Vertebrate Collections (contributing to the physical infrastructure of OU, Ohio, and the USA), and we CT scanned, again, hundreds of modern-day and fossil specimens which we have made available in open-access digital data portals (contributing to the cyberinfrastructure of, again, OU, Ohio, and the nation), including NSF-funded portals such as MorphoSource. Although the studies of modern-day species certainly informed our studies of dinosaurs, they also were important studies on their own. But the dinosaur studies have been groundbreaking, shedding new light on new anatomical systems and new species. Huge amounts of 3D data were generated, archived, and disseminated, representing a significant contribution to cyberinfrastructure. The project attracted diverse scientists to lend their expertise, fostering new collaborative research networks.

Broader Impacts: The cranial kinesis project was innovative in integrating public outreach into its core, using social media (Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, Instagram, Sketchfab, blogs, etc.) in innovative ways, mainstream media (news releases, TV/radio documentaries), and plain-language video treatments of primary research. A major success was basically ?exploiting? dinosaurs, that is, using dinosaurs as a palatable outreach tool to talk about more sophisticated STEM subjects to a broad global audience??they come for the dinosaurs but stay for the science.? Our team did huge numbers of live public outreach programs in rural Appalachian Ohio, both visiting local schools and libraries but also conducting workshops and tours of the lab. The cranial kinesis project lives on past the grant and will continue to benefit society by exploiting interest in dinosaurs to talk meaningfully to a very broad audience about evolution, biology, scientific methods, and the value of science generally. From this initial project, we are building an even broader network of scientists, educators, media arts professionals, and even policymakers to realize the full potential of the project.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2021
Modified by: Lawrence M Witmer
